title: Expanding Pore Size of Al-BDC Metal–Organic Frameworks as a Way to Achieve High Adsorption Selectivity for CO
/CH
Separation
abstract: The mesostructured Al-BDC metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with an average pore size of 2.58 nm were prepared via a simplified washing and drying process and applied to the separation of CO
mixtures. The adsorption equilibrium and thermodynamics of CH

were studied in the dynamic processes by the volumetric–chromatographic and inverse gas chromatographic (IGC) methods. The experiments represent that the Al-BDC MOF with large pore size has a much higher CO
selectivity of ca. 24 at 303 K in the pressure range 0–1.0 MPa and therefore appears to be a good candidate for the separation of CH
. The initial heats of adsorption of CH
on the mesostructured Al-BDC MOFs were determined to be 11.5 and 25.2 kJ mol

by the IGC method, respectively, which are significantly reduced by ca. 25% compared with that on the microporous Al-BDC MOFs. The results indicate that the expanded pore size not only greatly increases the selectivity of CO
but also reduces the adsorption heat, revealing that it should be the desired method to obtain a satisfactory absorbent for CO
text: Natural gas (NG) is one of the cleanest carbon fuels due to its low CO

and particle emissions after combustion and has become one of the fastest growing primary energy sources in the world. The huge demand for natural gas has led to a re-evaluation of the development potential of unconventional, stranded, and contaminated gas reserves, which contain much more than 2% CO
from these NG reserves is critical for natural gas transportation and usage because it significantly reduces the energy content of natural gas and also induces pipeline corrosion.
The amine-based absorption/stripping process has been used for the separation of CO
from natural gas for a long time,
but the solvents used, such as aqueous alkanolamines, usually require high energy and often lead to environmental issues due to solvent loss and degradation.

Adsorption-based separation methods, such as pressure swing adsorption (PSA), temperature swing adsorption, and membrane processes, are commonly accepted to be the most efficient and affordable, but adsorbent regeneration is still difficult and energy costly, leading to low productivity and great expense.
Nonetheless, PSA has the advantages of easy control and low energy demand and is considered as one of the better choices for CO
The vital step in designing PSA processes for the separation of CO
mixtures is the development of adsorbents with a high CO
selectivity, excellent regeneration properties, and high thermal stabilities.
and new classes of porous materials
have been investigated for their CO

adsorption behaviors. Thereinto, activated carbon and silicas have been widely studied as adsorbents owing to their stability, low polarity, and low energy intensive regeneration operations, and the main drawback is the low selectivity for CO
On the other hand, zeolites are mostly adequate for separating CO
due to the preferential adsorption of CO
in the polar cavities and channels of relatively aluminum-rich zeolites.
However, the high affinity of zeolites for CO
hinders its desorption, which leads to low productivity and high regeneration energy cost.
Clearly, to better satisfy the needs of the CO

separation, the separation performance of conventional adsorbents, such as zeolite, activated carbons, and silica gels, should be strengthened. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been emerging as promising materials in applications of adsorption separation, owing to their flexibility to design through control of the architecture and chemical functionality of the pores. Up to date, many different MOFs have been explored to examine their performance on the separation of CO
gas mixtures, both experimentally and theoretically, such as Zn(bdc)dabco,
All of these studies have demonstrated that these MOFs exhibit high selectivities for CO
mixtures, and the selectivities for CO
on some MOFs are more than 10, revealing that MOFs could act as the alternatives of conventional adsorbents for CO

separation. However, only a few of these MOFs can be synthesized in large scale from low-cost raw materials under available conditions, which is of paramount importance for MOFs becoming a realistic adsorbent for CO
Furthermore, most of the MOFs with higher stability have not exhibited higher selectivity of CO
than conventional adsorbents such as zeolites and activated carbons.

Very recently, immobilization of functional sites to induce their stronger interactions with carbon dioxide, or control/tune the pore size/curvature to maximize the size-exclusive effects, has been used to improve the CO
separation selectivities of the above-mentioned adsorbents. For example, amines, the OH group, and Li
have been grafted onto surfaces of porous materials to enhance adsorption of the CO
molecule on conventional adsorbents and MOFs.

In addition, a novel “molecular sieving” effect, which is based on a difference in ability of a guest molecule to induce temporary and reversible cation deviation from the center of pore apertures, has been uncovered on Cs
Obviously, these modified adsorbents have much higher affinity to CO
, and some of them exhibit record high selectivity for separation of CO
Unfortunately, specific interactions of adsorbed CO
molecules with the surfaces increase the selectivity of CO
while reducing the regenerability of adsorbents; that is, the regeneration property of adsorbents must be considered while enhancing CO
selectivity by the method of modification.
On the basis of the above analysis, the desired adsorbent for CO
separation should have a high CO
capacity, high selectivity, and the fitting affinity to CO
. Although a lot of MOFs have been employed to study the CO

, it is still far from satisfactory for natural gas upgrading owing to many reports limited to single-component measurements or simulations. In the present work, we report the enhanced adsorption behavior of CO

on Al-BDC MOFs by the increased pore sizes. First, Al-BDC MOFs were prepared via a simple method fit for industrial use, and the pore size of Al-BDC MOFs was enlarged by a simplified washing and drying process. Subsequently, the adsorption equilibrium and thermodynamics of CH
were studied in the dynamic process by the volumetric–chromatographic and inverse gas chromatographic (IGC) methods.
The Al-BDC MOF material studied in this work was synthesized according to the previously reported modus operandi.
In a typical synthesis, 40 g of Al(NO

BDC) were dissolved in a 600 mL of DMF. The resulting stock solution was decanted into ten 120 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves, which were capped tightly and heated to 160 °C in an oven. After the reaction under the autogenous pressure for 12 h, the products were allowed to cool to room temperature. The white precipitate was isolated from the mother liquor by filtration and washed thoroughly with 200 mL of DMF and then immersed in 200 mL of fresh methanol to exchange the DMF over 12 h and then washed with 200 mL of methanol. The as-produced samples were then evacuated to dryness at 100 °C for 4 h and designated as AlBDC

samples was finally heated to 350 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min and treated for 45 h in a muffle furnace, defined as AlBDC

Al-BDC MOF pellets were prepared from the as-produced powders through a binder-free forming process, which was conducted by a tablet press applying a mechanical pressure of 60–70 atm. The obtained pellets were crushed and sieved to the particles with the average size of 80 μm that were then used as adsorbents.
The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted for 2θ values from 5° to 65° on a Rigaku RINTD/MAX-2500PC diffractometer (Cu Kα, 40 kV, 100 mA) with a step size of 0.02°.

The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed on a Nicolet 6800 equipment with an MCT-A detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. IR spectra were collected by recording 32 scans at a resolution of 6 cm
with samples in potassium bromide pellets.
Surface area and pore characteristics of the Al-BDC MOFs were confirmed by the N

physisorption measurements at 77 K on a volumetric sorption analyzer Autosorb-iQ2 from Quantachrome Instruments U.S. equipped with a high-resolution pressure sensor. The experimental apparent specific surface area, the total pore volume, and pore size distributions (PSDs) were calculated from these adsorption isotherms. Prior to analysis, the Al-BDC sample was outgassed at 180 °C under dynamic vacuum for 12 h.
The thermal stability of the Al-BDC MOFs was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) coupled with differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), which was carried out in air (20 mL min
) using a NETZSCH STA 449 F3 analyzer. In the TGA run, a Pfeiffer vacuum OmniStar mass spectrometer was used to investigate the chemical nature of the species leaving the sample.

C solid-state NMR measurements were performed on a Varian Infinityplus-400 spectrometer equipped with a 5 mm magic angle spinning (MAS) probe at a resonance frequency of 100.5 MHz with a spinning rate of 8 kHz.

C CP/MAS NMR spectra were performed with a contact time of 2 ms, a recycle delay of 2 s, and 2100 scans. SEM images of the Al-BDC MOFs were obtained on an FEI Quanta 200F microscope operated at 60 Pa and 30 kV. The sample was fixed on a copper holder with conductive adhesives. In addition, the density of Al-BDC MOF pellets was measured by the conventional mercury intrusion method.
